title: Impetus
description: A program about books that have given shape to the 20th century.

title: Child beyond
description: Documentary-drama with discussions by child-care experts about exceptional children, both handicapped and gifted.

title: Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra
description: This series presents performances by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Max Rudolf.

title: Transatlantic forum
description: Presented by the British Broadcasting Corporation in collaboration with the National Educational Radio Network, this series brings together experts from the United States and Great Britain to discuss a topic.

title: America Street, U.S.A.
description: In the city of Sunnyvale California, there is a street named America street. Families of many different backgrounds live on the street and in the immediate neighborhood. It's a melting pot of America in miniature. What are the feelings, the attitudes, the texture of life on America Street? What do these Americans think about America as it is today? For if we are to approach the reality of the American experiment in democracy we must know, understand, and respond to the opinions of America Street. We ask you to imagine that you are overhearing a discussion among the residents of America Street as occasionally compared and contrasted with an informed opinion from other sources.

title: Poetry and the American
description: This series profiles notable American poets.
Twenty half-hour programs designed to further the enjoyment of poetry.

title: Youth on a four day trip
description: This series focuses on teenagers and various aspects of their health.

title: Gateway to ideas
description: This series of conversations focuses on ideas in relation to reading.
This discussion series, produced by the American Library Association, features noted authors, critics and scholars on various topics related to reading.
This discussion series, produced by the American Library Association, features noted authors, critics and scholars on various topics.

title: Behind the classroom door
description: A weekly series exploring specific challenging aspects of public education.

title: Creative method
description: This companion series for The Creative Mind presents radio essays on a creative activity by an outstanding representative of that activity. Dr. Lyman Bryson hosts.

title: Prospect of a union
description: A first-hand account of the founding of the United States, described through the correspondence of John and Abigail Adams.

title: How do you say hello?
description: A series about children and the places they live, with a focus on developing countries.

title: West meets east
description: A series about the relationship between the United States and countries in Asia, with an emphasis on how Americans understand Asian experiences and culture.

title: Writer as critic
description: Discussions with authors about their subjects and methods.

title: A federal case
description: A weekly review of government affairs produced in Washington, D.C.

title: The African revolution
description: A six-part study of Sub-Saharan Africa, based on a fifteen-country tour that was undertaken by broadcaster Harry Ruskie.

title: 1970 May festival
description: The 1970 May Festival from Music Hall in Cincinnati, Ohio. The festival featured the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra and other performers.
The 1970 May Festival from Music Hall in Cincinnati, Ohio. The festival featured the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra and other performers.

title: The Urban Frontier
description: Each program in this series considers one of the major life activities people carry on in an urban setting.  The format is narrative with dramatized interludes.

title: Seminar: Big Sur
description: Discussion and lecture series from Esalen Institute at Big Sur, Calif., headed by Michael H. Murphy devoted to exploring the psychological nature of man.

title: The reader's almanac
description: A series intended to connect listeners with interesting and significant books and authors.

title: Ways of mankind II
description: This series is an exploration into the origin and development of cultures, customs and folkways in various parts of the world. This second series of Ways Of Mankind is concerned with a specific subject area and with two specific cultures.

This series is an exploration into the origin and development of cultures, customs and folkways in various parts of the world. The second series of Ways Of Mankind is concerned with a specific subject area and with two specific cultures.

title: The music of Don Gillis
description: This series features the works of Don Gillis; hosted by the composer himself. Most of the performances are conducted by the composer.

title: Munich '72
description: A series of five-minute programs previewing the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, West Germany.

title: BBC world theater
description: This series presents performances of great plays, both classic and modern.

title: The jazz international
description: A series exploring jazz music from twelve different countries.

title: As I roved out
description: Hosted by folksinger Jean Ritchie, As I Roved Out explores folk music of America and the British Isles and the people who make it.

title: Negro spiritual
description: Talks by Rolf Cahn, folksinger and musicologist, with music from records, including replays from old collections.

title: Latin American perspectives
description: A series of comment and analysis about current affairs in Latin American countries.

title: Report to Congress & the Nation On Health Care
description: The following hour-long program presents a taped summary of National Public Radio's six public hearings on problems facing America's health delivery system. In Boston, San Francisco, New York, Philadelphia, Ann Arbor, Michigan, and Atlanta. We heard many opinions expressed. Some more from experts. Others were from simple people who have had problems obtaining health care.

title: This was Toscanini
description: A documentary honoring the 100th anniversary of the birth of conductor Arturo Toscanini, hosted by Brigette Paolucci.

title: The theory and practice of communism
description: The Theory and Practice of Communism is a series of lectures taken from the 1967 Wisconsin Alumni seminar held at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. The speaker, Michael B. Petrovich, is a specialist in Russian and Balkan history, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin, and the author of numerous articles and books.

title: WFCR non-drama series
description: This series presents an experiment in sound sensations, asking audiences to view the works as abstract, surrealistic sound paintings that create an environment.

title: The border in question
description: Documentary series on U.S.-Canadian relations, from a Canadian point of view.

title: Got the blues
description: This series focuses on blues music and its history.

title: Beethoven: The man who freed music
description: A series of programs reviewing the musical, social, and political climate during Beethoven's lifetime.

title: Writer and the welfare state
description: A group of writers from various parts of the world gather in Copenhagen to discuss the place of the writer in modern society.

title: Creative mind
description: This series, hosted by Lyman Bryson, presents radio essays about the creative process for the American artist and scientist in the 20th century.

title: News in 20th century America
description: A radio series on the gathering, writing, and dissemination of news. Compiled from interviews with men and women who make news their business.

title: Book beat
description: This series introduces listeners to contemporary leading authors, literary critics, and book publishers.

title: Exploring the child's world III
description: Interviews with delinquent and disturbed young people who are encouraged to discuss their experiences and express feelings. To protect individuals, each program is a re-creation of an actual interview using different names and places.

title: National Association of Educational Broadcasters Convention
description: These recordings featured highlights from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters 40th Annual Convention in 1964.
These recordings featured highlights from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters Annual Convention.

title: Hall of song: The 'Met,' 1883-1966
description: Documentary series on history of the Metropolitan Opera Company ("The Met") in its original home at Broadway and 39th Street in New York. "The Met" closed its old location on April 16, 1966. Series includes interviews and rare recordings of noted performers.

title: CSAA Annual Conference: Sexual behavior and social ethics
description: Recordings from the Child Study Association of America's 42nd annual conference.

title: Conversation with Georgists
description: Produced in cooperation with the Henry George School of Social Science, this series explores economic topics including protection, free trade, wages, taxes, automation, and unemployment.

title: 31st Annual Couchiching Conference, 1962
description: The 31st edition of an annual meeting held in Geneva Park, Ontario. Political matters are discussed, with an emphasis on how they relate to Canada. This edition focuses on "The New Europe."

title: The comic arts II
description: Essays and interviews on the nature and scope of humor in America. Program consultant for the series: George Q. Lewis of the Humor Societies of America.

title: A federal case II
description: A series examining current issues facing the United States and the Washington, D.C. area.

title: Great decisions
description: This series explores various topics related to foreign policy.

title: Exploring the child's world
description: Interviews with delinquent and disturbed young people who are encouraged to discuss their experiences and express feelings. To protect individuals, each program is a re-creation of an actual interview using different names and places.

title: Century of science
description: A recorded exploration of science and its importance to the 20th century American.

Discussions of aspects of science affecting modern America. This series is hosted by Volta Torrey, the director of radio and television programming at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as well as the former editor of Popular Science.

title: Frank Weil lectures
description: Presented by the Frank L. Weil Institute, the lectures in this series explore topics related to psychiatry and ethics.

title: News Report on G. Alexander Heard, chancellor of Vanderbilt University
description: A report on Vanderbilt chancellor Alexander Heard, who was extended an invitation to fill the newly created post of adviser to President Nixon on campus affairs on issues of concern to students—including the Vietnam War and the military expansion into Cambodia. This program provides an overview of the chancellor’s meetings with the administration.

title: Listen to the land
description: A profile of a nation in terms of its living language. By sharing aloud the writings of the United States, past and present, a fuller appreciation of what it means to be American can be found.
America's literary heritage is explored through readings of short stories, poems, folklore, journalism and legends. The series is narrated by Richard S. Burdick.

title: Torchbearers of science
description: This series explores France's pioneers in the field of scientific endeavor.

title: Music now
description: A series focused on American composers of the mid-Twentieth century.

title: P.M.
description: This evening series focuses on news and current affairs in Great Britain.

title: Amang the Scots
description: A documentary series about modern Scotland.

title: The negro American
description: A lecture series by professor Benjamin Quarles of Morgan State College, Baltimore, made in late 1967 in the Detroit Public Schools. The series covers one topic each week.

title: British general election
description: The outcome of the 1964 general election in Great Britain is explored by various journalists and politicians.

title: The music of Don Gillis III
description: This series spotlights the works of American composer Don Gillis and is hosted by the man himself.

title: Bernard Gabriel
description: A series of interviews with musicians, writers, archivists, and other experts focusing on topics related to music and culture.

title: News in twentieth century America
description: A series of documentaries on the gathering, writing and dissemination of news in this country today, compiled from interviews with journalists. Guests in this series include H.V. Kaltenborn, Roy Larsen, John Daly, Douglass Cater, Drew Pearson, Quincy Howe, Mike Wallace, Norman Cousins, David Brinkley, James Hagerty, Howard K. Smith, Marquis Childs, Merriman Smith, Gilbert Seldes, Fulton Lewis, Jr., Sig Mickelson, H.R. Baukhage, Roscoe Drummond, and many others.
A radio series on the gathering, writing, and dissemination of news. Compiled from interviews with men and women who make news their business.

title: The Institute on Man and Science
description: A lecture and discussion series on major current problems like urban decay; pollution; space exploration; and the role of science in finding solutions. Talks were held during the summer of 1968 at the Institute on Man and Science, New York.

title: Backgrounds of music
description: Hosted by John Brownlee, this series seeks to provide in-depth discussion of important music.

title: The V.D. epidemic
description: A series about a venereal disease epidemic in the 1960s, especially among teenagers.

title: Tender twigs
description: This series discusses problems affecting today's youth, such as mental health, delinquency, crime, social pressures. It also considers solutions for parents and youths to employ.

title: Security and civil rights
description: Interviews on balancing national security interests with personal liberty.  The series is moderated by Monrad Paulsen of Columbia University.

title: A conversation with
description: Eminent musicians discuss their careers and the art of music. The series is co-hosted by Arrand Parsons of Northwestern University School of Music and George Stone, WEFM program director.
A series of programs with musicians discussing their careers and thoughts on topics related to the art of music.
This series provides listeners with an opportunity to hear musicians talk about their own music, as well as other related issues.

description: This series features recordings of Cincinnati Symphony concerts.

description: This series features lectures from the Perspectives in Development conference, which was presented by the League of Women Voters Educational Fund, the Overseas Development Council, and the Johnson Foundation.

description: This series features interviews with outstanding scholars from various fields.

description: This series explores current developments in research in the fields of the behavioral sciences and medicine.

title: William Allen White
description: The story of William Allen White is a saga of a boy born in the heart of rural America who chose to stay there yet became a confidante of presidents and one of the world's most influential citizens. On the 100th anniversary of the famous journalist and editor's birth, this program features an address by his son, William L. White, at the University of Kansas.

description: Historical documentary series drawn from the recollections of senior citizens in a variety of American towns.

description: The thoughts of distinguished Americans in a survey of American eduction.

description: A report on the House Commerce Committee hearings on the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.

description: Recordings of noted organs at various locations throughout Europe.

description: This recording focuses on broadcasting practices.

title: The Asia Society Presents
description: The Asia Society Presents was a weekly 25 minute program designed to promote a better understanding by Americans of the Far East. Host Lee Graham interviewed a wide variety of experts on the region. The series began in November 1967.

title: 29th Annual Couchiching Conference, 1960
description: The 1960 Couchiching Conference, a summer symposium on national and international affairs put together by the Canadian Institute on Public Affairs and the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, assembles for its 29th annual meeting. The theme of the 1960 conference was "The Latin Americas."Every night at this time for the next week we're going to hear speakers from various Latin American countries—statesmen, scholars, businessmen—to talk among themselves and with colleagues from the United States, Great Britain, and Canada about the problems facing their various countries and in particular how these problems can affect Canadians. During the week we'll have first hand reports on the political upheavals which have occurred in the south and the enormous social and economic revolutions which are now in progress.

title: About science
description: Interview series on variety of science-related subjects, produced by the California Institute of Technology. Features three Cal Tech faculty members: Dr. Peter Lissaman, Dr. Albert R. Hibbs, and Dr. Robert Meghreblian.

title: March of medicine
description: Dramatizations of great moments in medical history.

description: This series focuses on music created and performed by African-Americans, including folk, and jazz styles. This series is hosted by Anton Luckenbach of Carbondale, Illinois, who also gathered interviews in New Orleans for this series.

title: Peninsula Music Festival
description: Live concert performances from the Peninsula Music Festival in Door County, Wisconsin.

description: This series focuses on air pollution and its impact on America.

description: Profiles of curious figures in the American past, based on diaries, journals and other books of personal record.  The speaker is Robert E. Streeter, a professor of English at the University of Chicago.

description: The 1961 Couchiching Conference, a summer symposium on national and international affairs put together by the Canadian Institute on Public Affairs and the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, assembles for its 30th annual meeting. The theme of the 1961 conference was "diplomacy in evolution."

description: This series explores the drug scene in Vancouver, attempting to understand why people use drugs.

This series presents problems facing educators today.

title: New England renaissance
description: A dramatic re-creation of the New England Renaissance produced at Boston University.

A dramatic re-creation of the New England Renaissance produced at Boston University. In this part of the series, the Transcendentalists are viewed from the perspective of 1954, when this program was recorded.

title: Canada '67
description: This series focuses on Canada's Expo '67 celebration and other events celebrating the 100th anniversary of the founding of Canada.

title: The real eastern Kentucky
description: This series focuses on various topics related to society and culture in eastern Kentucky.

title: Special of the week
description: Drawing from various series and stations, Special of the Week explores a wide range of notable topics with expert speakers in each episode.
Special of the Week #2. Dr. John C. Kuhl, director of Community Development Division of the U.S. Mission in Laos.
Special of the Week #1. Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Abraham Ribicoff at his first news conference, Feb. 1961.
Special of the Week #4. Centennial of Italy unification: ceremony at Library of Congress.
Special of the Week #3. Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman and U.S. Chief of Protocol Angier Biddle Duke in separate interviews.

Special of the Week #6. Formation of the Peace Corps. Includes excerpts of speeches by Senator John F. Kennedy during 1960 presidential campaign at University of Michigan, and Professor Maurice Albertson, appointed to study the viability of a Peace Corps.
Special of the Week #5. Attorney General Robert Kennedy at his first news conference, speaking about organized crime and racketeering.  Also: Chancellor of West Germany Konrad Adenauer.

description: A series of explorations into effective living, combining dramatizations with commentary.

description: This series presents special performances of music from Germany.

title: The Chicago lectures
description: This series presents lectures given at University of Chicago, focusing on the nature of human beings, their place in the universe, and their potentialities. The lectures were also published in The Bulletin of Atomic Scientists, beginning in September 1965.

description: Music-documentary series in 26 parts, covering various aspects of jazz.

title: The smoking dilemma
description: A series about the complexities of the smoking problem, hosted by Dr. Ralph Grawunder, San Diego State University.

title: New world of atomic energy
description: About peacetime uses of atomic energy, with experts from Oak Ridge and other atomic energy centers.

title: Ruffled feathers: The Dakota Sioux
description: A documentary series about the history, culture and contemporary problems of the Sioux, a Native American tribe.

title: One nation indivisible
description: A documentary series about nationalism in the 20th century.

title: National Educational Radio Audio Visits
description: A series of conversations between National Educational Radio staff provided as audio updates for educational stations.

title: New aspects of language
description: A discussion series about linguistics featuring students and faculty from Nashville University Center and led by Dr. Gerd Fraenkel of the George Peabody College for Teachers. Produced by WPLN and the Nashville Public Library.

title: The merry adventures of Robin Hood
description: A series of recorded readings from the book "The Merry Adventures of Robin Hood" by Howard Pyle.
A series of readings recorded by Chuck Levy, from the book "Merry Adventures of Robin Hood" by Howard Pyle.

title: Egoist in tragedy
description: Three lectures by David Grene, poet, translator, and Professor in the Committee on Social Thought, University of Chicago.  He discusses a particular kind of tragedy and focuses on three examples.

title: Organ music of the centuries
description: Highlights of noted organ music selections from various periods, including Pre-Baroque and Baroque; Classical and Romantic; and Modern.

title: Classical drama
description: This series presents full-length productions of Greek and Roman plays of antiquity in modern English translation with original music especially composed for this series.  Each play is introduced by William Arrowsmith, University of Texas.

This series presents full-length productions of Greek and Roman plays of antiquity in modern English translation with original music especially composed for this series.  Each play is introduced by William Arrowsmith of the University of Texas.

title: Atoms for power
description: This 15-part series discusses the feasibility of atomic power as an alternate energy source to replace depleted fossil fuels.

title: What a piece of work is a man
description: Aldous Huxley presents a lecture series in which he asks, "how did our ancestors think of human nature and in what terms ought we to think about it?"

title: Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra 1966
description: This series presents performances by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Max Rudolf.

title: The truth about radio
description: A series that features interviews with important figures in the radio industry.

title: Twentieth century America: Its folk and popular music
description: This series focuses on various contemporary forms of folk and popular music.

title: Up the down staff
description: A series of conversations about music.

title: Dwight MacDonald on film
description: Series of lectures by Dwight MacDonald on film: its makers, its history, its future.

title: Ernest Bloch: The man and his music

Documentary/music series about the life and work of the late Swiss composer Ernest Bloch, featuring his daughter, Suzanne, of The Julliard School of Music. With her commentary are readings by actors, including Robert Morris. More info next entry.

title: Smoke?
description: Series on smoking and health; approved by the American Cancer Society.

description: Series exploring artistry of cellist Emanuel Feuermann, including historic recordings. The series is hosted by Seymour Itzkoff of Smith College.

description: For series info, see Item 3338. This prog.: Is Art a Form of Communication?

Series featuring discussion of controversial aspects of modern and contemporary art. Panelists: Lawrence Alloway, former curator of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City; Gerhart Magnus, Southern Illinois U.; Walter Richter, WSIU. Modern art.

title: Man and the value of life
description: A series about the ethical, technical, and legal issues involved in extending human life through medicine.

title: Portrait of the American
description: Series that examines assessments of the American using the themes of innocence, affluence, success and the American self. Features analysis by Dr. Betty Ch'maj, interviews, dramatic readings. Series features interviews with John Dos Passos, James Farmer, Marshall Fishwick, Alan Harrington, Ihab Hassan, Irving Howe, Alfred Kazin, R.W.B. Lewis, and William H. Whyte, Jr.

title: Music from Rochester
description: A series of concerts from the University of Rochester's Eastman School of Music, featuring students and faculty as performers and composers. Recordings of concerts from 1968-69. No other information available.

For series info, see Item 3481. No information available this program.

title: Seminars in theatre
description: A weekly panel discussion series on the theatre scene in New York City, moderated by Richard Pyatt.

title: Monteverdi
description: A discussion of the work of Monteverdi, hosted by Newell Jenkins and featuring musical illustrations.

title: Success in the arts
description: This series presents panel discussions that focus on various aspects of the arts, including the skills needed to excel. The series is moderated by Studs Terkel and produced by Alfred E. Partridge.

title: Sounds of poverty
description: A documentary series featuring interviews with rural Appalachia residents by one hundred students from twenty-nine colleges, meeting at Action for Appalachian Youth Conference at Ripley, West Virginia. The series is hosted by Bert Cowlin.

title: Mainland China in the 1970s
description: This series of lectures explores contemporary life in China.

title: Law in the news
description: This series focuses on current news stories that relate to the law.

title: Split the lark and you'll hear the music
description: A special that focuses on the poetry and letters of 19th century American poet Emily Dickinson.

title: 20th Century Music for Piano
description: A series of performances of 20th century piano compositions as well as interviews with the performing artists.

title: Operation Airlift: 20th anniversary
description: Documentary in observance of 20th anniversary of June, 1948, Berlin Airlift, breaking the Soviet blockade. Produced by Deutsche Welle.

title: Improvisation Chamber Ensemble
description: A series of performances by Wayne State University Improvisation Chamber Ensemble, which was organized in 1966 by Dr. Ruth Shaw Wylie, as an experiment in teaching contemporary techniques to advanced composition students.

Series of performances by Wayne State U. Improvisation Chamber Ensemble, which was organized in 1966 by Dr. Ruth Shaw Wylie, as an experiment in teaching contemporary techniques to advanced composition students. Refer also to blue spiral book under 67-29.

title: Nuremberg and Vietnam: Who Is Guilty?
description: My Lai was a war crime and violated established international laws which the United States has long accepted. It was a specific crime, and in the last few days we've heard allegations of other crimes with the charges against Gen. Donaldson. Tonight we're going to examine whether in a far broader sense the United States has violated international law by its conduct in Vietnam.

title: This land, this heritage, this people
description: This series traces in word and music the footprints of America, the turns we took, the tales we spread. Narratives, letters, diaries, and songs have been adapted from primary source materials by Professor Robert E. Gard, director of the Wisconsin Idea Theater. Features Professor Gard as well as guitarist-singer Kent Toepfer.

Series featuring readings from letters, diaries, books and narratives, interspersed with songs of the times. Features Prof. Robert Gard, director, Wisconsin Idea Theatre; and Kent Toepfer, guitarist-singer.

title: The diary of Samuel Pepys
description: This series dramatizes portions of the diary of Samuel Pepys, an English naval administrator who provided invaluable writings from the English Restoration period.

title: And the world listened
description: This series presents dramatizations of famous speeches.

title: BBC world theatre
description: This series presents performances of great plays, both classic and modern.

title: New directions in social sciences
description: A series of talks delivered before the annual convention of the American Psychological Association in San Francisco.

title: NER concerts
description: National Educational Radio presents a series of recorded concerts.

title: American composer
description: Original works by American composers commissioned for this series. The compositions are meant to highlight important American holidays or seasonal observances.

description: This series presents concert performances from the Chicago Contemporary Chamber Players.

description: A history of American radio programming from the 1920s to the present day.

description: Lectures on the 1968 U.S. presidential campaign by political scientist Max Lerner of Brandeis University, presented in late 1968 at Garland Junior College in Boston.

title: Report from Russia
description: E.W. Ziebarth, Dean of the summer session at University of Minnesota, and ten other faculty members embarked upon a month-long trip through the Soviet Union. Ziebarth interviewed his peers about their thoughts on the trip.

description: This series analyzes European views of the works of American authors.

title: American language
description: A series of talks by Mitford Mathews, editor of the Dictionary of Americanisms and lecturer in linguistics at the University of Chicago.

title: Politics in the twentieth century
description: This series consists of moderated panel discussions on American political affairs in the mid-20th century. It features Samuel Lubell, Professor Charles Nixon and others.

title: Newsdesk
description: This British news series addresses major headlines of the day.

title: Beyond Vietnam
description: A speech by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., given at Riverside Church in New York City, April 4, 1967, and sponsored by Clergy and Laymen Concerned About Vietnam.

title: Search for new values
description: The series presents speeches by leading figures in science.

title: Assembly for Human Rights: Montreal
description: This special series offers highlights of a 1968 international gathering held in Montreal, Quebec, bringing together some 80 unofficial delegates and observers from all parts of the world. The assembly was presented in connection with the current International Year of Human Rights declared by UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization).

title: Unfinished business
description: A series of programs designed to acquaint listeners with unresolved social welfare problems.

title: Pensions: An old-age problem
description: This program was brought to you as a public service by the president's commission on pension policy.

title: I Pledge Allegiance
description: Every day school children pledge their allegiance to this piece of cloth, yet few citizens stop to consider what allegiance to a flag means, nor why they give it. Is it a convenient propaganda device to promote unthinking obedience to a government? Or is it a god-inspired symbol of brotherhood justice and prosperity? On this program we propose to explore the meaning and function of the American flag. We will consider what it means when we say “I pledge allegiance.”

title: Advances in science
description: This series explores questions related to science and peace.

title: Opera: Battleground of the arts
description: A discussion series, hosted by Boris Goldovsky, that examines the welding together of music and drama, two distinct arts, into opera.

title: U.S. foreign policy: Demands of the next decade
description: On the occasion of its 50th anniversary, the Foreign Policy Association of the United States organized a traveling conference based on the theme "demands of the next decade." This is a series of recorded speeches from a 1968 Portland, Oregon, conference sponsored by the FPA, the World Affairs Council of Oregon, and Time Magazine.

title: Evolution of jazz
description: Jazz historian Nat Hentoff presents a series that traces the history of jazz, from its musical and cultural roots to its contemporary forms.

title: Over the back fence and Transatlantic profile
description:
A cross-section of Canadian opinion from the press of your
northern neighbor. These viewpoints on national and international
events are taken from newspapers from coast to coast. The program is compiled each week as a service to American listeners by the Canadian
Broadcasting Corporation.

title: National Association of Educational Broadcasters 41st Annual Convention, 1965
description: These recordings featured highlights from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters 41st Annual Convention in 1965.

title: Music in the making
description: Instructional comments and musical illustrations using faculty and students from the Millikin University School of Music. The first thirteen programs in the series focus upon historical aspects of music. The second half of the series explores music's technical side.

title: Radio Smithsonian
description: This program features music and conversation from the Smithsonian Institution.

title: The Jeffersonian heritage
description: This series dramatizes the ideas of Thomas Jefferson, which are "the enduring possessions of all Americans and all free peoples," while being "authentic in historical spirit" and "imaginative in form."

title: Perspectives on violence
description: This series presents speakers from a thirteen-part conference on the United States in the 1970s titled "Perspectives on Violence," part of an annual undergraduate project at the Johns Hopkins University.

description: A series of lectures featuring Dr. C. Harvey Gardiner, professor of history at Southern Illinois University, about current Latin American problems and their historical setting.

description: This series offers the latest world headlines at lunchtime.

title: New England anthology
description: A series featuring New England poets who read and discuss their own works.

title: The American cowboy
description: Documentary series on the American cowboy, produced by the University of Texas.

title: Coming of age
description: Explores the thoughts and feelings of American youth in the 20th century. Writer-director Ben Park talks with teenagers and parents, teachers and friends.

title: Peace, love, creativity: Hope of mankind
description: This series presents lectures from the 1968 Cooper Union Forum. This forum's theme is Peace, Love, Creativity: The Hope of Mankind.

This series presents performances by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Max Rudolf.

title: Tales of the valiant
description: Dramatic stories of great national heroes outside the English-speaking world.

title: Four documentaries
description: Produced by the Children's Foundation in Washington D.C., this series of four documentaries explores various social issues including the effects of drugs on children, the experiences of Native Americans and Mexican Americans, and poverty and charity funds.

title: Ethic for broadcasting
description: This series presents interviews that center on issues in broadcasting and society.

title: Community education project
description: Produced by the Community Education Project at San Bernardino Valley College, this series raises issues facing individuals who live in or near cities.

title: Artist speaks
description: Leading artists of the time speak about their own works.

title: The yankee dollar
description: A documentary series on impact of U.S. dollar on Latin America, especially Mexico. Ther series is hosted by Richard Arellano.

title: The LaSalle String Quartet II
description: This series presents performances by the La Salle Quartet of Cincinnati, Ohio.

title: The urban confrontation
description: Urban Confrontation is an analysis of the continuing crises facing 20th century man in the American city, covering issues such as campus riots, assassinations, the internal disintegration of cities, and the ever-present threat of nuclear annihilation. Produced for the Office of Educational Resources at the Communications Center of the nation's largest private university, Northeastern University.

title: Kaleidoscope
description: A series of close-ups of the American art scene.

title: Meet Mr. Emerson
description: This series presents a survey of excerpts from Ralph Waldo Emerson's lectures, journals, and essays.

description: A documentary series that examines prisons and their purposes.

title: Washington report
description: A weekly news report produced in Washington, D.C. for stations of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.

title: Musica Popular Mexicana
description: In this series of programs, we explore the regional music and dance forms of Mexico, with special emphasis given to the history and culture of the Mexican people. These programs are presented in cooperation with the Department of Music and the Center for Intercultural Studies in Folklore and Oral History at the University of Texas at Austin.

description: Illustrated lecture series featuring 34 piano sonatas of Haydn as demonstrated by Canadian pianist Raymond Dudley, Concert Artist in Residence at the University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory.

description: A series of recorded lectures and discussions from the Cooper Union forum.

title: Window on the world
description: A series of short talks by well-known British personalities on the subjects usually associated with them.

description: British Broadcasting Corporation interview series about the October, 1968, Olympics at Mexico City. Includes interviews with athletes Jim Ryun, Ron Clark, Gaston Roelants, Elaine Tanner, Bobby McGregor.

title: U.S.-U.S.S.R. exchange programs
description: A series of program created within the Soviet Union for listeners in the United States. It is produced as part of a Soviet-American agreement for cultural exchange.

title: Where minds meet
description: A series of discussions exploring world of speech, conducted by Professors John Freund and Arnold Nelson of Western Michigan University
Discussions explore world of speech, conducted by Professors John Freund and Arnold Nelson of Western Michigan University

title: In memoriam: Langston Hughes
description: A series about the noted American poet who died May 22, 1967. It features him reading his poetry at Columbia University during Spring 1964.

title: Music and other four letter words
description: This series explores the possibilities and functions of music beyond entertainment.

title: Last citizen
description: A series of programs devoted to exploring the problems facing African-Americans and how these issues impact all Americans.

title: The legendary pianists II
description: Music by great early-twentieth century concert pianists who produced Duo-Art piano roll recordings before advent of electronic recording.

title: Donald P. Kent memorial lecture
description: The Donald P. Kent Memorial Award is given annually to a member of the Gerontological Society of America. The award winner then delivers a lecture related to the subject of gerontology.

title: Do not fold
description: The University of Illinois radio service presents a series of programs about you and the computer. From banks to hospitals and from airlines to music, its applications seem endless. These programs will give you a glimpse of these countless applications and what they mean to you.

title: America on stage
description: Selected American plays written prior to 1900.  Each is an expression of contemporary popular sentiments.  Radio adaptations of theatre performances, using selected excerpts.

title: Hard travelin'
description: A series about Woody Guthrie and his Depression-era folk music.

title: The next fifty years
description: A series of lectures recorded in Autumn, 1967 at the American Institute of Planners Conference, Washington, D.C. The emphasis is on projected urban needs for the next fifty years, including city planning, housing, architecture, recreation, and transportation.

title: World this weekend
description: This hour-long series features news and commentary from Great Britain and around the world.

title: Faculty recital
description: A recording of an instrumental music performance.

title: Dilemmas of power
description: This series presents a variety of lectures on Soviet-American relations. The lectures are followed by informal question and answer sessions.

This series presents a variety of lectures on Soviet-American relations that were given at the Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium in Baltimore, MD. The lectures are followed by informal question and answer sessions.

title: The wandering ballad singer
description: Folk music series hosted by musician Barre Toelken, who collects folk songs and has worked as a dance band musician, a Forest Service employee, and prospector.

title: Public Broadcasting Act of 1967
description: A panel discussion on the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967. Moderated by Edgar Willis, former program associate for National Educational Television. Panelists: Edwin Burrows; Ben Yablonki; and William Pearce.

title: Library of Congress lectures
description: A series of lectures given at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

title: My own master
description: A documentary-drama commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of journalist William Allen White, owner-editor of the Emporia Gazette and a major figure in the Progressive movement.

title: Man is not a thing
description: This series presents a discussion of the discoveries and errors of Sigmund Freud and his impact on the American family, politics and religion.

title: The inner core: City within a city
description: A documentary series on urban conditions for residents of the Inner Core of Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

title: Behavioral science research
description: A documentary series on behavioral science and its role in understanding human health.

title: Comment on a minority
description: This series explores minority issues in the United States in the mid-20th century.

title: Composer in the world of today
description: How the composer of today sees the contemporary world around him. Interviews, commentary and musical illustration provide a better picture of the modern composer. The series is hosted by Burrill Phillips, composer and professor of music at the University of Illinois.

title: National Drug Prevention Radio Spots
description: A series of anti-drug spots produced by the U.S. Department of Health, Education, and Welfare.

title: What about you?
description: An educational program designed to illustrate the dangers of cigarette smoking for young people.

title: Exploring the child's world II
description: Interviews with delinquent and disturbed young people who are encouraged to discuss their experiences and express feelings. To protect individuals, each program is a re-creation of an actual interview using different names and places.

title: Speaking of Mexico
description: Panel discussion series about Mexico.

title: Birmingham Campaign
description: This is a collection of audio segments pertaining to The Birmingham Campaign, a non-violent protest against segregation in Birmingham, Alabama, and the racist policies of public safety commissioner Theophilus Eugene “Bull” Connor. The recording includes speeches by Ralph Abernathy, Sr. and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

title: The Middle East War
description: A series of five 10-minute analyses of the Six-Day War by British Broadcasting Corporation Middle East correspondent James Thompson.

title: World tonight
description: This series features news and commentary on world events with reporting from London and Paris.

title: Business roundtable
description: A program of current comment from leading members of America's business community.

title: National Association of Educational Broadcasters 40th Annual Convention, 1964
description: These recordings featured highlights from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters 40th Annual Convention in 1964.

title: Document:  Deep South
description: A series of documentaries depicting the increasing importance of the South in the economic development of the United States. Narrated by Walt Whitaker, written and produced by Leroy Bannerman, with Dr. Walter B. Jones as senior consultant.

title: NHK Symphony Hall
description: A series of symphonic performances recorded at the NHK Hall in Tokyo, Japan

title: Music in our time: 1969
description: This series presents performances of contemporary music.

title: One plus one equals three
description: This series explores the problems created by population growth.

title: The story of education
description: This series presents various excerpts from the book, "The Story of Education," which traces the evolution of education. The excerpts are read by the book's co-author, Dr. Carroll Atkinson.

title: UN Human Rights Day Concert
description: One in a series of annual concerts celebrating the adoption and proclamation of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), the first global enunciation of human rights and one of the first major achievements of the new United Nations.

title: World of the rockhound
description: A series focusing on America's popular craft hobby rockhounding, which includes gem cutting, making jewelry, and collecting gemstones, rocks, minerals, and fossils.

title: Contemporary music in evolution
description: This series explores the various schools and lineages of contemporary music.

title: Lincoln as a social prophet
description: A series of readings from letters and speeches by Abraham Lincoln, prepared and delivered by Marvin Ceynar, speech instructor at Northern Illinois University.

title: The U.S. Senate Class of 1971
description: This year, eleven freshman--five Republicans, five Democrats and one conservative--joined the ranks of the 100 and America's upper house of the legislative branch of government. This series interviews each of the incoming senators.

title: Reader's almanac
description: A literature series featuring interviews with authors, poets, and others in the literary world.

title: Hazards to education
description: Walgreen Lecture series on the present hazards to American education as seen and presented by Robert M. Hutchins.  Each lecture discusses one particular problem.

title: Search for mental health
description: A series of talks about the latest advances in psychiatry by staff members of Forest Hospital near Chicago.

title: Pathways to progress: The Great Lakes
description: A 13-part documentary drama about the economic impact of the Great Lakes region in the United State.

title: The world of education
description: This series explores various aspects of education in Great Britain.

title: New England Conservatory
description: A series of concerts featuring performances by faculty and students from the New England Conservatory of Music.

title: Report from abroad
description: Based on the travels of a Purdue University modern languages professor and his wife, this series considers differences between life in Europe and the United States, as well as recent changes in European life.

title: The story behind the theatre
description: This series explores the factors that combine to make a dramatic presentation coherent and meaningful for audiences.
Interviews with theatre professionals by Lyle Dye, Jr., managing director of the Equity Library Theatre of New York.

title: European review
description: European Review #393, recorded May 27, 1969.

title: The Washington Post columnists look at Richard Nixon after a year
description: For the next hour, twelve columnists who appear in the editorial pages of The Washington Post are going to talk about Richard Nixon's presidency. They will discuss what they have seen in the more than a year that he's been in the White House. All these journalists comment on a number of aspects of the federal government, but all of them have at one time or another written about the president's performance. You will hear from Tom Braden, Frank Mankowitz, David Broder, Marquis W. Chiles, Roscoe and Jeffrey Drummond, Roland Evans, Joseph Kraft, Chalmers M. Roberts, William S. White, and satirist Art Buchwald.

title: Pacific portraits
description: This series explores various aspects of the Pacific region through dramatization, narration, commentary and music.

title: The Music of Don Gillis II
description: This series features the works of Don Gillis; hosted by the composer himself. Most of the performances are conducted by the composer.

title: 28th Annual Couchiching Conference, 1959
description: About two hundred attendees from various parts of the world have gathered to talk about and hear about changing Asia, a matter of great concern to all of us in the world today. Too often we in the West tend to judge the attitudes and actions of Asian countries only from our own standpoint. At this conference we have tried to avoid this and have invited personalities from different Asian countries to come and explain to us in their own terms what is happening in India, Japan, China, Indonesia, and elsewhere.

title: American writers in Italy
description: A series focusing on American authors who wrote novels with Italy as the background.

title: Your doctor speaks II
description: In this series, doctors from the colleges of medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, nursing, and graduate college at the University of Illinois Medical Center in Chicago discuss the latest advances in cancer and heart research, painless dentistry, psychiatry, nursing care, modern drugs and more.

title: Sinclair Lewis's Minnesota
description: A series of 12 programs about what Minnesota means to Minnesotans through the work and experiences of Sinclair Lewis.

title: Crossroad in time
description: This series explores the changing way of life of the Athabaskan people in Alaska.

title: International classroom
description: This series of lectures explores philosophical issues in world relations.

title: U.S. and China
description: This series discusses contemporary relations between the United States and China.

title: A nest of singing birds
description: A series examining three centuries of English poetry.

title: Prepare for survival
description: A radio sounding board for facts and opinions on civil defense.

title: Man and the multitude
description: A lecture series commemorating the centennial of the University of Illinois.

title: Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra 1970
description: This series features live performances from the 1970 season by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra .

title: Bluegrass and mountains
description: Recordings of and talk about a wide variety of old time American music.

title: The old record box II
description: Musical and speaking selections played from cylinder records dated from the late 1890s to about 1929.

title: The legendary pianists
description: Music by great early-twentieth century concert pianists who produced Duo-Art piano roll recordings before advent of electronic recording.

title: Your Congress today
description: This series explores the relationships between the Congress and the Supreme Court and the Presidency.

title: Books in the news
description: No information available.
A quick look at newly published material and books of current interest.

title: The story of a masterpiece
description: For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: J.B. Greuze: The broken pot
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: Charles Le Brun: Portrait of Chancelier Sequier.
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: Edouard Manet: Olympia
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: Watteau: the emparquement for Cythere.
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: Pierre Mignard: The Virgin and the Child
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: Van Gogh: White Field with crows
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: Louis David: Napoleon's Coronation
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: Ingres, Rome Grand Prix

Semi-dramatic series about famous French masterpiece stories, produced by French Cultural Services, as part of its project Various Aspects of French Life. This prog.: J. Gericault: The Raft of the Medusa.
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: J.B. Van Loo: The Holy Family.
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: J.B. Perroneau: Portrait of de La Tour
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog.: E. Delacroix: The Death of Sardanapale.
For series info, see Item 3409. This prog. J. Goujon fashions the loveliest jewel in all of France.

title: Middle East crisis
description: A panel discussion sponsored June 1, 1967, by University of Chicago Center for Policy Study. Participants: Leonard Binder and William R. Polk of University of Chicago, Tahseen Bashir of Arab States Delegation, Benjamin Halpern of Brandeis University.

title: Your rights are on trial
description: Discussions and dramatizations of recent high court decisions.  Features Professors of Law Monrad Paulsen of Columbia University and Charles Alan Wright of University of Texas.

title: The American journal
description: This is an informal, "magazine" style interview series on the fine arts.

title: Seeds of discontent
description: For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Poverty stricken citizens in the inner city of Detroit discuss problems of shelter, food, clothing and recreation; they discuss plight of the poor, their hopes and disappointments.

Documentary series addressing: race relations, civil rights, poverty, youth, crime, deliquency. Host: Hartford Smith, Jr., Michigan Dept of Social Services and Wayne State U. This prog.: Smith visits a "hippie pad" and explores communal living.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: See also program #6. Older Negro men talk about Negro-police relationships, the riots, red-light districts, and the Negro community.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: See also program #6 and #7. Continuation of same discussions: Negro-police relationships, the riots, red-light districts, and the Negro community.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Negro bassist Leslie Grinage gives an inside look at the problems facing Negro performers.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Guests: Odetta, Dick Gregory, Leslie Grinage on what should be done in entertainment field.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Problems of the Negro in general society are discussed by Odetta, Leslie Grinage and Dick Gregory.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Feelings and attitudes about contemporary welfare systems. See also programs #3 and #4.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Interviews with Negro professionals and middle class members: psychologist, newspaper editor, car salesman.

For series info, see Items3313-14.This prog.: Historical perspective on problems of the Negro. A group of older Negro men, residents of Detroit upwards of 40 years, describe why the Negro left the South, what he was looking for and what he found in north.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Political and social attitudes of the Negro professional man.

For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Negro folk artist Odetta looks at her experiences, problems and concerns; in so doing she describes the problem of the Negro in becoming established in the entertainment world.

For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: As previous program (#3) but centering this time around medical care and effects of poverty on various ethnic groups such as poor Negroes and southern whites.

For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: The American Negro and public education, as a source of both hope and frustration. Addresses serious problems confronting present day school systems in large metropolitan areas.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: The emergency of black self-help groups in Negro ghettos. A look at current crises and needs in urban centers throughout the nation.

For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Campus unrest, student demonstrations. The growing discontent and rebellion of college students. Interviews with student activists at Wayne State U. who are in conflict with "the establishment."
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Growing discontent and militancy among public school teachers. Features interviews with teachers from the inner city schools of Detroit.

For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Looking at the future through the eyes of Negro children attending two predominantly black junior high schools bordering on the two largest housing projects in Detroit.

For series info, see Items3313-14. This prog.: An assessment of the attitudes and reactions of established agencies and institutions as reflected by their programs in response to urban society's unrest and discontent. United Community Services of Detroit.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Assessment of the response, attitude and relevancyof Detroit's Poverty Program, including an interview with the director.
For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Assessment of the response, attitude and action by the Michigan State Legislature in the aftermath of the Detroit riots of 1967.

For series info, see Item 3313 and 3314. This prog.: Hartford Smith, Jr.'s, observations, comments and conclusions regarding the nature and meaning of discontent in American society, and what needs to be done.

title: People talk back
description: This series presents a series of questions posed to politicians about current affairs.

title: Audition reel
description: Audition reels that were distributed to promote new radio programs on the National Association of Educational Broadcasters network.

title: Revolution: 20th century phenomenon
description: A series of lectures from the 26th annual Institute on World Affairs, a special feature of the instructional program at San Diego State College. The institute seeks to present and discuss current and continuing issues of international significance, focusing on the theme of revolution.

title: Speaking of Mexico: English
description: This series discusses issues related to Mexican life, government, and culture. This is the English-language version of Speaking Of Mexico.

title: Voices of Europe
description: Interviews with noted Europeans on a variety of subjects, conducted by Milton Mayer, American author and broadcaster, lecturer and professor in the Institute of Social Research at Frankfurt University.

relatedFolders.title: Foundations, Standard Oil of New Jersey, 1953

title: Christmas Special 1969
description: A special radio program produced at the University of Michigan to celebrate the 1969 Christmas season.

title: Georgetown forum
description: Moderated by Wallace Fanning, this series presents a panel of guests discussing a variety of topics. The radio series launched in 1946. It also later aired on WTTG-TV in Washington, D.C. These programs aired 1968-69.

title: Recital hall
description: Outstanding musical performances from University of Texas faculty and students, as well as guest performers.

title: The music makers
description: Distinguished Americans discuss their profession of music, from composition to criticism; the business of music and its current place in our national culture.

title: Make history your hobby
description: This series provides detail and analysis of important historical figures and events.

title: Ways of mankind
description: This series is an exploration into the origin and development of cultures, customs and folkways in various parts of the world.

relatedFolders.title: Foundations, Standard Oil of New Jersey, 1953

relatedItems.title: Ways of Mankind - A Preliminary Report (August 7, 1953)
NAEB Region II Seminar Workshop Report (March 13-14, 1953)

title: Ideas and the Theatre
description: The series presents a discussion of the current American theatre; its values, beliefs, patterns, and problems. Participants include Arthur Miller, Eric Bentley, Gore Vidal, Brooks Atkinson, Cyril Ritchard, Clinton Wilder, Tennessee Williams, and others.

title: Scrolls from the Dead Sea
description: The story of the Dead Sea Scrolls, featuring interviews with 30 leading scholars, scientists, archeologists and theologians.

title: Challenge 69: The urban crisis
description: Presented by Wake Forest University's Symposium on Contemporary American Affairs, this series focuses on the problems of American cities.

title: American composers 20th century almanac
description: A series of original compositions by young American composers commissioned and recorded by the University of Michigan broadcasting service.

title: The multiversity today
description: A series about today's large university and its complexities and problems as seen by students, faculty, alumni and employees.

title: Contemporary revolution in Latin America
description: This series of documentary reports focuses on the contemporary revolution in Latin America.
A documentary series on problems facing Latin America, including panel discussions at program conclusion. The series is hosted by Erwin Canham, editor at the Christian Science Monitor.

title: Aspects of mental health
description: A documentary series on the role of behavioral sciences and medical research.

title: Birth control today
description: A series about birth control and how it affects society.

title: Indian country
description: The problems of social adjustment in the attitudes and through the words of the modern American Indian.
The problems of social adjustment in the attitudes and through the words of the modern Native Americans.

title: Light unto my path
description: This series explores the books of the Old Testament, how they were written, how they were preserved, and why they continue to have influence.

title: Issue and inquiry
description: This series explores contemporary social and political topics.

title: Toward a new world
description: Lectures recorded at San Diego State College's 25th Annual Institute on World Affairs. The Institute brings together world leaders to discuss issues in politics, culture, science, and more.

title: Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra 1971
description: This series features live performances from the 1971 season by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra .
This series features live performances from the 1971 season by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra

title: World of the Paperback
description: This series is dedicated to the discussion of literary topics and of the publication of significant paperbound books.

title: Fifty years of growth
description: A series of documentaries on industrial change in the U.S.

title: Konrad Adenauer specials
description: Special programming commemorating the life of Konrad Adenauer, chancellor of West Germany from 1949 to 1963.
